Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 11:42AM - edited Mar 21, 2008 11:44AM by bluewillow Hello to all! I haven't been here in a while, but thought I'd pop in and see how everyone is doing.  I just finished tx #17 and am just now "feeling the burn"!  The rads office is closed today for Good Friday, so I'm glad to get a break, especially from the drive. I have enjoyed catching up on your posts, and I have some questions for you all!  Has anyone had a "weird" feeling during radiation?  I woke up this morning with a strange feeling that I can't pinpoint, but it's almost a flu-like feeling, but I don't feel sick-- slightly achy, chilled sometimes then I sweat, almost like a low-grade fever. I didn't sleep well last night because of the full moon (I'm not a werewolf-- just can't sleep unless it's pitch black dark!), but oddly I feel energetic otherwise.  I have been taking 1 mg of Ativan daily (.5 mg in the morning and then .5 mg right before bed), but have done without it for the past two days.  Could my weird feeling be withdrawal from the Ativan?  I sure wish I could do without it, but it sure helps with the anxiety.  The rads techs have told me not to try to lose weight during radiation, but to maintain.  They said it would interfere with the mapping for the radiation.  Not what I wanted to hear, because I gained 20 lbs during chemo that I must get off soon!  Has anyone else been told not to lose weight?  Just checking to make sure they're not feeding me a line of horse-hockey!  Ok, one more question-- has anyone noticed feelings of depression during rads?  Sorry if someone has addressed this already.  For the past week or so, I have felt "down" after weeks of feeling pretty good.  All my lab work came back normal, so physically I am ok.  I think if our weather here in western NC would improve and be steadily mild, instead of a nice 65 during the day and 26 freezing cold degrees at night!! Well, that's it for my whining and list of questions.  I hope everyone has a great weekend and a nice Easter!   And continued best wishes for everyone during rads! Hugs, Mary Jo

Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 03:20PM bluewillow wrote: Hi there Lynne, I had my last chemo on Jan. 28 (started with Adriamycin/Cytoxan on Sept. 17 and finished with Taxol), and I definitely had vision changes from the chemo.  I had to buy stronger reading glasses and my distance vision was affected too.  I asked my oncology nurse about having a vision check, and she suggested that I wait about 6 more months before making an appointment with the eye doctor, and she confirmed that chemo does affect vision.  I have noticed an improvement since finishing chemo-- things are not as blurry at a distance.  Hope this helps and I wish the best to you and your friend! Posts.Content: bluewillow wrote: Hello everyone! I had my bi-monthly checkup today and talked at length with the Nurse Practitioner at the cancer center, mainly about some issues with depression I am having right now.  The depression came on fairly suddenly-- I was sailing right along after radiation, then bam it hit-- and she said that was exactly typical of BC-related depression.  She suggested three things that would help: Exercise, Anti-depressant medication, and Psychotherapy (I don't even know what that is!)  Well, the exercise is a no-brainer-- I definitely need it, but I am not sure my insurance will pay for psychotherapy, so I went with the A-D in the form of Effexor.  Has anyone out there taken Effexor and have you had success with it?  I am starting out on a very low dose and working up to increase.  The NP also said it would help with hot flashes and night sweats, which is a BIG plus!  Anyone had experience with psychotherapy?  What is it, exactly? THANKS, HUGS, and best regards to all! Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 01:24PM bluewillow wrote: Hello everyone, Sorry I haven't been posting much these days, but I have been lurking and checking in when I can.  I have 14 more tx left and I am just now feeling pain, although it's not bad... yet!  I am getting sore underneath my breast and it is hard to keep that area dry and aired out, especially at work!    My armpit is just as tan as can be-- a place that has never tanned before except in the tanning bed, where I spent a lot of time in my late 20's into my early 40's-- I have to wonder if that may be the cause of my BC?  Probably not, but it makes me think and cringe... What kind of bath soap are you all using? I need to ask that today at the rads center, if I can remember it then.  I guess I could pin a note on myself like little kindergartners get in school...  Hey Sue in NC-- I just read your post about your friend with the mass.  I tried to put myself in your position, and that would indeed be tough to handle while trying to put this cancer stuff in the past.  But I think I would try to stay in touch with her and find out how she is and what her tests reveal and support her as best you can. You sound like a very warm and compassionate person and probably would not feel right just ignoring her, PLUS you've got to remember- her situation is not you and your case is very different and you are going to be absolutely fine!  But if you decide that you can't handle being too close, then don't beat yourself up for it, ok?  I do believe it is very, very important to stay close to positive people and those who uplift you instead of bringing you down (BC or not)  I think we have the right to make the choice of who we are close to during our ordeal. I recently spoke with a lady who does the same job with school bus routing in another western NC county that I do here, and she is 7 years out from her breast cancer and she is doing so great!  She told me that I have to remember that I am cancer-free thanks to the surgery, and that I have to get out there and live my life wide open.  She also advised me to walk every day, and thanks to her advice, I went to the gym last night, walked for a measly 30 minutes (but hey, better than none), and I feel SO MUCH BETTER! I slept better than I have in many months, so I think I have found the key to my well-being now! Gotta go for now-- talk to you all later!  Hugs and best wishes to all! Mary Jo

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2008 01:47PM - edited Apr 26, 2008 01:49PM by bluewillow Hello ladies! Sorry I haven't posted much, but I have been reading about you all and I hope you all are doing well on this Saturday morning! I finished my rads on April 17 and am SOOOOOO glad!!!  Although I miss the rad techs, I don't miss that drive every day, esp. with gasoline at $3.60 a gallon here!  ouch!  I had very little problems with rads except tiredness, and looking back, I should have taken more time off from work and rested.  I am so glad to finally be wearing my "good bras" again, instead of the non-supportive camisoles!! WhEEEE!!  I am feeling absolutely wonderful, except for lots of aches and pains and stiffness.  If I sit a while and then get up, oh, it hurts!  But when I walk a little ways, all the stiffness and pains go away.  I had these before BC, so I'm not freaking out or anything, but I do wish I knew what was causing this.  Oh wel, at 51, I suppose the aches and pains are normal.  I blame the extra weight too, so the hurtin' is making me get back on my fitness and weight loss wagon! I have a question for you ladies:  while I was taking chemo and rads, I was told not to take antioxidant supplements, etc.  But now that I am finished with everything except for Herceptin, is it safe to get antioxidants in the form of green tea?  I absolutely love Lipton Diet Green Tea, and I was drinking it by the gallons before BC.  Anyone know if this would be detrimental to the lasting cancer-fighting effects of the chemo and rads?  LUVmy2girlsZ, I just saw your post about the water bottles-- thanks for posting it!  I have been increasingly concerned about this too and even my daughter is very upset because of the baby bottle issue (thankfully she is breast-feeding but does use bottles sometimes)  I am wondering if anything plastic is safe.  Now that I am a baby-boomer, I think back about all the plastic that has entered my lifetime, way before any testing or regulations.  Do we just throw away our plastic?  What would you use to transport hot lunches in?  Or do we just ignore all this and hope for the best?  (that's hard for me to do) Hello to Sue in NC, Sue in NJ, Tay, Ulla, Doe, mpellot, climbergirl, Larousse, Darah, Tina, PAlady, Quinnie, 12954, DeAnn, kajo, and all the others I might have missed!  I wish I had made time to post more, but I feel like I know you all from just reading!  I hope everyone is doing very well and enjoying their journey back to WELLNESS!!! Love to all, from Mary Jo

Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 12:15PM - edited May 6, 2008 12:16PM by bluewillow Hi everyone! I need your help, but that is all explained (or should I say 'vented') in my last paragraph... I hope everyone is enjoying a nice Springtime day!  It sure is nice and sunny here, although we had a cool start this morning.  And have you voted yet?  I voted at 7 a.m. and there sure weren't the crowds that were predicted.  Maybe they'll come later on today. Whatever our beliefs or party affiliation, I think it's imperative that we exercise our right to vote!   Ok, on with my whining... I had a major meltdown last night!  I received an invitation to a Survivor's Dinner to be held tonight, in connection with Relay For Life, and I agreed to go, since my good friend and co-worker, who is also a BC survivor, is going to be the guest speaker.  I'm really looking forward to the dinner, but the reason for my meltdown was not related to my cancer, or fear of it, etc., but was because I am SO FAT and I am not doing anything about it!!!!!  I had my meltdown after trying on clothes that I was sure would fit but didn't, but it wasn't even the clothes thing.  It was the realization that after a breast cancer diagnosis and all the terror and treatment that I've gone through, I'm still not taking good care of my body by dieting and exericising and losing the weight I gained!!!  I am just plain mad at myself for the 20 lbs I've gained, knowing that obesity and lack of exercise can actually cause a bc recurrence!!  So, what is wrong with me?  Why can't I get going with my weight loss program?  I know exactly what it takes, have all the "tools" and "know-how" to do get it done-- but I have hit a brick wall ! I want to live to grow old with my husband, to see my grandson enter college, to go on my dream vacation to southern Oregon, and I just keep eating junk and sitting on my big fanny!  Sorry if I sound so worked up, but I am scared-- what does it take to change and get started?  Have any of you out there had the same problem?  To make matters worse, my husband gave me no support and told me he "didn't want to hear me squawling", because he is disgusted with me too for not making a better effort to start eating better and working out.  It's just the two of us and my schedule is pretty much mine, and I buy all the groceries, so it's not like there's anything stopping me but me! HELP HELP HELP!  Any suggestions?  Thanks, dear ladies, for listening to a big 51-year-old cry-baby/whiner! And, To all of you who are doing the walks and marathons, you all are AWESOME and I admire you so much for your efforts!!!  Love you all! Mary Jo

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2008 10:39AM bluewillow wrote: Hello everyone! I hope all of you are doing well-- even though I don't post a lot, I still think about you all and send best wishes! Yesterday was a very interesting, stressful, tiring day for me.  I had my checkup with the radiation oncologist yesterday morning and he said I had healed very well and doesn't need to see me again until November.  I asked him about when I should have another mammogram, since I was due for my yearly one June 1.  He told me to wait 3-4 months until after my last rads tx, which was April 17.   I was ok with that, sort of.  I still have my good left boob that I need to watch over, so I mentioned this to my chemo nurse yesterday afternoon when I went for my Herceptin treatment. She said she'd check w/my dr. there and she came back and said "you're due now for a mammo, how about today?"  SO, after my Herceptin was finished, on to the breast imaging center downstairs I went to get BOTH boobs squashed.  It wasn't as painful as I'd expected for my right one  Now the agonizing wait for the results, although the mammo tech did tell me "not to lose any sleep and nothing jumped out at her".  That doesn't make me feel much better because these techs have been wrong before.  But I'm trying not to worry. Questions:  have you all had your follow-up mammos yet and how long did you or your doctor advise to wait until after rads were completed?  Should I have waited the full 3-4 months after rads?  I hate it when one onc says one thing and the other onc says another...  and I trust them both very much.  Thanks for your help and hugs to all! Mary Jo

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2009 12:53PM - edited Nov 12, 2009 01:05PM by bluewillow Hi everyone!  I haven't been on the forums in a while until the other day and that was to ask for recommendations for a good makeup for my tired, dry skin. (anyone here have ideas?)  I found this great new topic for early stagers and just thought I'd chime in here and say "there IS life after chemo, rads, Herceptin, stool softeners , steroids, endless dr. appointments, etc., and YES, there are thoughts that DON'T include breast cancer.  And hair DOES grow back (I am back to hating mine again )  If I may, I'd like to recommend a book that really helped me, and it was written especially for Stage 1 and 2 ladies:  the title is Just Get Me Through This!: The Practical Guide to Breast Cancer, by Deborah A. Cohen. (forgive me if someone has already mentioned it).  Amazon.com has it and it is well worth the price.  I am a Stage 1 survivor of 2 years.  Yes my boob still hurts and my scars still itch, but life does get better.  And to prove that life gets back to "normal"-- my forgetful mind just realized today that exactly one year ago, I had my final Herceptin treatment. I'm doing great and living life even better than before my dx.  Hopefully this is some encouragement for you ladies currently going thru treatment and I hope I have helped someone in some small way. Those of you who are still in treatment-- HANG IN THERE and to those of you who are done-- CONGRATULATIONS! Hugs and best wishes to everyone!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 06:26PM bluewillow wrote: Hi Lori, Yes, you DO know squat!    Fall is the main season here for bowhunting if you choose to hunt deer (or bear).  You can hunt turkey with a bow or shotgun, but that just lasts about four weeks.  Bow season for deer lasts from early September until mid November with a pause for muzzleload season.  We also have rifle season from November to December, but you can also use bow and arrow during rifle season, which we normally do if we can find a safe place to hunt.  I want to try bowfishing so badly, but the bow and accessories that I want runs about $400.  Hopefully I can find some used equipment that will cost much less.  I also like the sun and water, and I would also love to go deep sea fishing some day.  Can you believe I can't swim a lick and love to be on the water?  Paxton, I say go for the Florida trip-- it sounds wonderful during the winter months!  What part of FLorida?  I have an aunt in Melbourne and a cousin in Tampa and I have been to the Panhandle, Jacksonville, Orlando, and to Key West and just remember warmth and sunshine everywhere... see ya! Mary Jo

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 01:43PM - edited Mar 21, 2008 01:44PM by bluewillow Hey there everyone!  Glad everyone is doing well!  I just posted on the Feb. rads site and thought I'd hop over here again-- I love reading your posts because most of you all have "been there, done that" already with the rads, and you all are so upbeat! Posts.Content: bluewillow wrote: Hello,  I have questions about traveling shortly after treatments end and am hoping for some responses from the chemo/rads "veterans" out there that have already finished treatment. (and yay for you all!)  I am currently doing 4 DD A/C with my #4 being tomorrow, the 29th.  I will begin 12 weeks of Taxol on Nov. 12 and 1 year of Herceptin, followed by 4-6 weeks of radiation at the end of the Taxol.  If I have figured on my calendar correctly, providing that all goes well, that would put me finishing up Taxol at the end of January and rads about the first or second week of April 2008, and we want to travel in May 2008.  My question is:  is it unreasonable to plan a long trip a month after tx ends?   We had this trip planned before the dx last summer, and my husband is determined to take me to see beautiful Oregon and Washington (where he was born).  I have not been farther west than Nashville, and never flown, so this is exciting for me.  What's funny is, before BC, I swore I'd never fly-- now I can't wait to get on that plane!  I am hoping you ladies who have ended your tx can give me some input on how you felt, what you did a month afterwards, if you would have felt like a long vacation, etc.  I guess I will still be Miss Baldy but that's ok. I plan on talking to my dr. more about it next month, because we need to make reservations!  We already know where we're going, staying, seeing, and what airline, etc., but we don't know the exactly dates in May yet.  I am getting more excited every day and can't wait to get this going!  And I am not into putting off things any more-- never again-- if I can help it! Thank you all so much for your help! Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2007 04:39PM bluewillow wrote: Hi Mary, Thanks for your great story and congratulations on your chemo being behind you!  You have given me such hope and also some great advice!  I had my first chemo yesterday and decided beforehand that I refuse to get sick, and so far I haven't!  I had a couple of very brief queasy spells yesterday after treatment, but after I ate a light snack and moved around some, those went away immediately.  And I slept like a baby last night, even with the steroids. I worked a half day today with no problems (would have worked all day but had to go get my Neulasta shot- a piece of cake there too).  I really believe that mustering up a positive attitude is helping me, and you have boosted me up even more!  I don't even fret about my pending hair loss any more, because I know it will be back! I wish you luck with the chemopause, and I plan to ask my dr. about the evening primrose oil- have heard it works wonders.  I am menopausal but had to stop my Vivelle Dot patch and the night sweats aren't fun, but not unbearable.  Exercise helps that symptom too! Again thanks so much for your reply- you are very inspirational! Mary Jo

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2008 06:21PM - edited Dec 26, 2008 06:23PM by bluewillow Hello everyone, I was looking back at some old posts I'd made and found this one with some very good information-- I'm not trying to toot my own horn here-- I just thought I'd bump it up for anyone who might be going through chemo and wondering "do you ever feel like your old self again"... and I must say, YES YES YES!!!  Or, maybe even better!!  Just my personal story:  I made it through chemo, radiation, and one year of Herceptin, kept working right along, had my port taken out Dec. 8 and I feel absolutely wonderful!!!  Life has taken on a new and better meaning, and my days are filled with lots of great things, namely a new grandson who is almost 1.  (My only residual complaint is the weight gain, but that is totally under my control, and I intend to get busy on a weight-loss/fitness program immediately)  So, for those of you going through chemo and think that you will not make it through, YES, YOU WILL!!!  And there IS life after breast cancer, as many ladies here will agree.  Hopefully some of the other chemo vets will post here too. Best wishes for recovery and good health in 2009! Mary Jo

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2007 09:48AM - edited Sep 14, 2007 09:49AM by bluewillow Wow, what awesome posts to my question!  Thank you all so much for the high hopes of getting back to "normal", even if it is a "new normal"!  Your input has been priceless and I do appreciate it! Gracejon, I think you said it so well about liking the new person that we become after enduring the therapies, and for having a new appreciation of life-- excellent point! Tina, I agree about looking past the doomsday crowd. There are a lot of them out there, even though some of them may mean well.  Glad you're doing so well and feeling great-- what an inspiration you are to us! Fumi, thanks so much for sharing your experience-- how wonderful that your se's were minimal!  You are a testament to the fact that we can look and feel well again and that sure give me great hopes that it can happen to any of us! Mamasj,so glad to hear you're getting back to your old self.  And I agree that taking it one day at a time is the only way to go!!!  I have a tendency to look too far beyond today and that just causes unnecessary worry, you know? Trigeek, you said it all so well!!!  I hope we can all realize what you have-- that life is all of a sudden better in a whole lot of ways, with a new perspective on everything.  And yes, Life is Good!! Harley, I'm glad your chemo hasn't been too bad for you and glad you're edging closer to the finish line!  I'm glad you've found hope and comfort in this post too.  After I was complaining about it being so dry here, it is raining buckets with a 100 percent chance of rain all day long!  Prayers are being answered! Take care, everyone-- Mary Jo
